item.title: ‚õëÔ∏è Bleeding per rectum
item.description: Bleeding per Rectum History # Bleeding per Rectum # Onset & Duration Colour Bright red Altered Mixed (fresh + altered) ‚Üí PPV higher when dark and bright mixed blood than dark or bright blood alone Melena (Sticky, blackish, difficult to flush) Timing with Defecation Before Mixed (towards malignancy) Streaky (fissure, low rectal CA) After Dribbling Spurting Amount? Cup/diapers/clots Any Other Bleeding Manifestations Associated Anal Pain? Fissure, abscess, hematoma, anal carcinoma Uncomplicated hemorrhoids or rectal cancer are not usually painful Any Lump at Anus?

item.title: üê¢ Tracheostomy
item.description: Surgical Anatomy of Tracheostomy: A Detailed Exploration # Tracheostomy, a surgical procedure involving the creation of an opening into the trachea through the neck, is a critical intervention in various medical contexts, from emergency airway management to long-term ventilation support. Understanding the intricate anatomy of the neck and the layered dissection involved is paramount for safe and effective tracheostomy placement. Anatomical Considerations # 1. Surface Anatomy: Tracheostomy is typically performed between the second and fourth tracheal rings, corresponding to the level of the cricoid cartilage (C6 vertebrae level).

item.title: üëí Bladder CA
item.description: Haematuria History # True Haematuria or Not # Exact Color: Dark tea color (OJ) Exclude Pseudohaematuria: Itching & steatorrhoea Factitious Haematuria: Munchausen‚Äôs syndrome, narcotic seeking behavior Past History # Bleeding diathesis & other bleeding manifestations Relation of Gross Haematuria to Urinary Stream # Initial (urethra distal to urogenital diaphragm) Total (bladder proper or upper urinary tract) Terminal (trigone/ bladder neck of prostatic urethra) Painless or Painful # Painless: Malignant but can cause pain due to clot colics Painful: Urinary tract infection or calculus, papillary necrosis, passage of clots, obstruction, loin-pain haematuria syndrome, glomerulonephritis Clots # Indicate non-glomerular bleeding Large, thick, irregular clots - bladder Small, linear clots - upper tract Passage of tissues Associated Symptoms # LUTS Fever, chills & rigors with loin pain or suprapubic pain Any loin pain with self-felt loin lumps (Classic triad of RCC 10% - haematuria+loin pain+loin mass) Tissue passage Vaginal or penile discharge, sexual activity Presence of urinary catheter Relation to menstruation (endometriosis) Anemic symptoms GU History # History of BPH, stone disease (Hx of GU cancers) Hx of instrumentation Hx of pelvic irradiation Aetiology for Malignancies # Smoking Occupational exposure to dye stuffs and rubber compounds Hx of travel to middle east countries (Schistosoma haematobium) Family history malignancy (bleeding diathesis + renal disease) Metastatic Features # Fitness for Sx PMHx- # PSHx- # Drug Hx- # Antiplatelets or anticoagulants, cyclophosphamide SHx- # Job(risk factors)/family Smoking/alcohol Disability/concerns Examination # General # Anemia/plethora Facial oedema/ periorbital oedema, rather than ankle edema suggest renal pathology Unilateral or bilateral ankle edema- think of Iliac vein compression in unilateral edema Bone tenderness Muscle weakness Malignant cachexia- anaemia asthenia anorexia Ask for BP Abdomen # Palpable suprapubic mass- distended bladder, anterior wall bladder tumor Ballotable renal mass Hepatomegaly Ascites DRE & genital Ex (non-reducing left varicocele) Summary # This 60 yrs old ASA 2, MET score >4, male patient with episodic visible haematuria over 3 months associated with occasional clots & passage of tissues.

item.title: Abdominoperineal resection
item.description: Abdominopernieal resection operative notes üè• # Comprehensive Guide to Abdominoperineal Resection ü©∫‚úÇ # Explore the intricacies of abdominoperineal resection (APR) with our detailed guides and resources. Our step-by-step instructions ensure precision and safety in every procedure. Essential Surgical Techniques üõ†Ô∏è # Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) ü©∫üîç # Learn the critical steps and techniques involved in performing an abdominoperineal resection, a crucial procedure for patients with rectal cancer. Preoperative Preparation: Patient Assessment: Detailed evaluation of the patient’s medical history and physical condition.

item.title: üë¢ Cauda equina syndrome, Acute foot drop & neurogenic claudication
item.description: Cauda equina syndrome, Acute foot drop & neurogenic claudication # Cauda equina syndrome # Triad of symptoms - Cauda equina syndrome (CESR) is deÔ¨Åned as a triad of symptoms including: bilateral lower limb radicular pain perianal sensory loss insensate urinary retention and subsequent incontinence. Often the Ô¨Årst symptom is the radiculopathy. Urogenital symptoms last. Terms Cauda equina syndrome (CESR) Cauda equina in evolution (CESE) = A patient progressing through these symptoms.

item.title: üëπ Radiculopathy
item.description: Radiculopathy # Introduction # Radiculopathy is a symptom generated by pathology affecting the nerve roots. Peripheral neuropathy is differentiated from radiculopathy by the distribution of the symptoms. Anatomy # The nerve roots ‚Äòradiate‚Äô from the spinal cord = radiculopathy. The root traverses four zones: the central canal (intrathecal); the lateral recess (within the root sleeve); the foramen; and the extraforaminal space . Pathology # Due to both compression and inflammation - ‚Äòchemical neuroradiculitis‚Äô.

item.title: üåï Lipoma
item.description: Often multiple lumps with smooth surface and spherical in shape with distinct irregular curve margins currosponding to the lobes. The “slipping sign” is not diagnostic.

item.title: üçá Pyogenic granuloma
item.description: A Hemispherical discharging nodule which grows upwards and outwards following a minor trauma. Initailly bright red, then become pale when it doubles in size just in few days.

item.title: üëã Hand
item.description: Hand # Pointing index Mallet finger Wasting of small muscles Wrist drop Wrist lumps ganglion Claw hand CTS De Quervain’s Tenosynovitis Principles of hand examination # Principles include includes inspection palpation Feel Move Range of movement Ease of movement Inspection invisible scars over common surgical sites contour of the hand discoloration and sinuses. Also check muscle wasting, Thenar eminence Hypothenar eminence dorsal side of hand the muscle bulk between metacarpal bones which is interosseous muscle Palpation.

item.title: üßÖ Sebaceous Cyst
item.description: Smooth tense spherical lump with a punctum presents for years. Often Multiple.

item.title: ü¶ø Joint
item.description: Major joints # Genu valgum Knee lumps CDH Limping Child Slipped upper femoral epiphysis CTEV Elbow lumps

Signs starts with A # 1. Aaron‚Äôs Sign # A sensation of pain and/or distress in the epigastric or precordial region on pressure over McBurney‚Äôs point in appendicitis. 1. Aaron‚Äôs Sign # A sensation of pain and/or distress in the epigastric or precordial region on pressure over McBurney‚Äôs point in appendicitis. 2. Abadie‚Äôs Sign # Charles Abadie: Spasm of levator palpebrae superioris muscle‚Äîa sign of Graves‚Äô disease. Jean Abadie: Insensibility of Achilles tendon to pressure, seen in tabes dorsalis.

Signs starts with B # 9. Babinski‚Äôs Sign (Not synonymous with Babinski‚Äôs Reflex) # a. Loss or weakening of the Achilles tendon reflex in sciatica. This sign helps distinguish true sciatica from hysterical sciatica. 9. Babinski‚Äôs Sign (Not synonymous with Babinski‚Äôs Reflex) # a. Loss or weakening of the Achilles tendon reflex in sciatica. This sign helps distinguish true sciatica from hysterical sciatica. b. In hemiplegia, the contraction of the platysma muscle on the healthy side is more pronounced than on the affected side.

Triangles in Surgery # 1. Hesselbach‚Äôs Triangle # Borders: Medial: Rectus sheath Superolateral: Inferior epigastric artery Inferior: Inguinal ligament Importance: Helps in differentiating direct from indirect hernias. 2. Bryant‚Äôs Triangle # Formation: Patient lies supine Line 1: From the anterior superior iliac spine vertically down to the bed Line 2: From the tip of the greater trochanter to join Line 1 at right angles Line 3: From the anterior superior iliac spine to the tip of the greater trochanter Importance: Diminution in the length of Line 2 indicates upward displacement of the greater trochanter.
